subtitle: Chapter seven man is as he thinks and
his thoughts are invariably created in

habitually therefore as man improves his

improve these mental conceptions
attention should always be concentrated
upon the ideal of everything of which we
think that is all thinking should move
toward the greater the larger and a
superior whatever we think about we
should always think about its idle side
its larger side and its superior side
everything is two signs the limited or
objective side and the unlimited or
subjective side when we consider only
the limited objective side of those
things we think about our mental
conceptions will be small superficial
and materialistic but when we consider

larger finer in a far superior worth the
capacity the power and the brilliancy of

conceptions are formed in the likeness

the mind will be inferior in every

and as ideal it is possible to make it
and to bring this about it is necessary
to train the mind to concentrate
attention upon the ideal side of
everything and to think with the larger

mental conception should be formed of
the mere external or personal side the

and permit those things to affect our
minds we form inferior and detrimental
conceptions in our own minds when we
think a great deal about the smallness
we imagine we see in others we tend to
breed smallness in ourselves but when we

side of the others we cause our minds to
rise in the scale and thus gain power
and understanding we never had before
in this connection a law is that when we

developed a superior in ourselves when
we think of the body we should not think

because the physical form will tend to
express the crude and the common when we

actions are low crude and coarse your

all such actions constitute or are
produced by the thought we think
therefore all our mental actions are as
crude or as fine as our thoughts

each one furnished most gorgeously with

we shall steadily develop our own mind

persistently hold in mind
therefore by directing our attention

will actually arise into mental
greatness
thus tending directly to develop

we should think of the unbounded

there is no greater subject for thought

therefore is vitally important as

thinking is thinking that produces the

should be formed in the likeness of
those facts that will be found back of

therefore instead of deploring the

will be unpleasant if we meet it with

misfortunes of life are usually looked

thought is
conducive to good results reverses come

they are simply opportunities to bring

attention should be at once be directed
